questions.question: Which ancient ruins is famous for its massive stone-carved amphitheater and was once a center for trade in the Arabian desert?
questions.context: This site was the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom around 400 BC and was largely unknown to the Western world until it was mentioned in the travels of Swiss explorer Johann Ludwig Burckhardt in 1812.

questions.question: Which UNESCO World Heritage Site, located in Southeast Asia, is renowned for its massive temple complex built in the early 12th century by the Khmer Empire?
questions.context: This temple complex is the largest religious monument in the world and was originally constructed as a Hindu temple dedicated to the god Vishnu before transitioning to Buddhist use.

questions.question: What location, known for the world’s oldest surviving stone building complex, offers clues to the lives of Neolithic humans who settled in the region over 11,500 years ago?
questions.context: This archaeological site has reshaped our understanding of the dawn of civilization and was first excavated by Klaus Schmidt in the 1990s.

questions.question: Which famous museum, home to the Mona Lisa, is located in a former royal palace?
questions.context: This museum in France is the world's largest art museum and was originally built as a fortress in the late 12th century under Philip II.

questions.question: Which site, a testament to Ancient Greek architecture, served as a backdrop for the debut of the Modern Olympics in 1896?
questions.context: This ancient site is the only stadium in the world built entirely of marble and hosted the first Modern Olympic Games installed by Pierre de Coubertin.
